column1: c_135781850.htm|2016-10-26| Commentary: Japan should contribute to promoting peace in Asia-Pacific|
by Xinhua Writer Chen Shilei
BEIJING
column2: Oct. 26 (Xinhua) -- As the Asia-Pacific is seeing a growing consensus that maritime disputes should be handled via direct talks among parties concerned
column3: Japan should stop stoking tensions in the region
column4: and truly honor its promise to make peace.

column1: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is on a three-day visit Wednesday to Japan
column2: a visit on which Tokyo has pinned hope to keep its ties with Manila tight amid concerns that Manila could ""separate"" from the alliance with the United States
column3: Tokyo's key ally in the area.

column1: The concerns were enhanced after Duterte
column2: a recalcitrant leader in Washington's eyes
column3: paid a visit last week to China at a time when China-Philippines ties have nosedived to a historical low due to the farcical South China Sea arbitration case brought by his predecessor Benigno Aquino III against China.

column1: In fact
column2: in the arbitration process
column3: Japan and the United States -- both outsiders in the South China Sea disputes -- have relentlessly supported the former Philippine government.

column1: Moreover
column2: Japan is trying to rope other countries into speaking out on the South China Sea issue.

column1: Tokyo is even planning on stepping up its activities in the South China Sea through joint training patrols with the United States and exercises with regional navies.
By stepping up its intervention in the South China Sea
column2: Japan hopes to sufficiently distract Beijing so that it will be unable to handle maritime spats with Japan in the East China Sea at the same time.

column1: Also
column2: Washington wants Tokyo to help implement its strategy of rebalancing to the Asia-Pacific
column3: and be a key counterbalance to a rising China. Japan seems to be quite cooperative in this.

column1: Right now
column2: peacefully resolving the South China Sea disputes through negotiations has become a consensus between China and other parties including the Philippines
column3: a major territorial claimant.

column1: And that is why Duterte and Chinese leaders were able to sit down together last week to discuss how to achieve overall improvement and greater progress in bilateral ties.
Of course
column2: Japan is free to develop its ties with countries in the region
column3: including the Philippines.

column1: But it is advisable that Japan abandon its ambition to stir up regional tensions
column2: and stop muddying the waters in the South China Sea. After all
column3: peace and stability in the region are also in its own interests.

Commentary: Rekindling Beijing-Manila ties carries no meaning for Philippine-U.S. alliance
by Xinhua writer Liu Chang
BEIJING
column2: Oct. 20 (Xinhua) -- Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is now in Beijing to warm up his country's ice-cold ties with China. The move has nothing to do with Manila's traditional alliance with Washington.

column1: As Chinese President Xi Jinping rolled out red carpet to welcome his Philippine counterpart on Thursday morning
column2: many around the world were predicting that the Southeast Asian nation was getting ready to pivot away from the United States
column3: its traditional ally.

column1: Some even said that Beijing would receive handsome gains if the Philippine-U.S. alliance truly gets weakened.h These observers are wrong although they think they have proofs as the new leader in Manila has been an open and fierce U.S. critic and threatened to cancel his country's joint military drills with U.S. armed forces.
The Chinese government never attempts to build up its ties with other countries on condition that these nations have to sacrifice their partnership with any third party.
To be more specific
column2: the most important thing Beijing seeks to get from a sound bilateral relationship with the Philippines is that the two sides can work together to strengthen their economic and trade cooperation on the basis of mutual benefit as well as respect for each other's sovereignty and territorial integrity.

column1: It's totally up to the Philippine authorities to decide how they are going to handle their relations with other parties
column2: including the United States.

column1: If America's partnership with the Philippines has indeed started to unravel
column2: perhaps the very first thing politicians in Washington need to look into is their own way of doing business with the country they consider as a key ally in the Asia-Pacific region. And it is unfair and meaningless to scapegoat either China or Mr. Duterte.

column1: They should also know that to sustain a partnership
column2: they need to at least learn how to be respectful and stop being bossy.

column1: Now that the Philippine leader is in China to fix the impaired ties
column2: he will almost surely return home with his hands full as the two nations are expected to reach a series of agreements and step up their cooperation in areas such as fruits trade and anti-narcotics.

column1: True friends need to be candid and honest. The visit is also a fine opportunity for the two governments to start their talks on the South China Sea dispute.
A proper handling of their maritime dispute
column2: especially after the law-abusing arbitration episode that led bilateral ties to fall to a historical low
column3: would build a solid foundation for the two countries to further their future cooperation without worrying that the island spats could relapse as time rolls on.

column1: BEIJING
column2: July 29 (Xinhua) -- The great expenses for the South China Sea arbitration unilaterally initiated by the former Philippine government should be made public
column3: as some Filipinos are already questioning the source of the money.

column3: denying China's long-standing historic rights in the South China Sea.

column1: Questions about how much money has been spent on the arbitration
column2: paid by whom and to whom
column3: have not only sparked hot debates in the Philippines
column4: but also drawn attention worldwide.

column1: It had cost Manila 30 million U.S. dollars to merely pay off legal fees and expenses of lawyers who prepared the case against China
column2: Rigoberto Tiglao
column3: former spokesperson and head of presidential office for former Philippine President Gloria Macapagal Arroyo
column4: wrote in an article published in mid-July by the Manila Times.

column1: This prompted a question
column2: raised openly three days later by former senator Francisco S. Tatad
column3: about the real cost of the arbitration. He suspected that the former Philippine government hid the truth from its nationals.

column1: The government ""never told the public how much the arbitration would cost the Filipino taxpayers. The Constitution provides that no money shall be paid out of the Treasury except in pursuance of an appropriation made by law
column2: yet no appropriation has been disclosed for this particular purpose
column3: he wrote to the Manila Times.

column1: How much then is it? Are any foreign donors involved?"" he asked.
The U.S. Central Intelligence Agency or its State Department should reimburse us
column2: said Tiglao
column3: suggesting that the arbitration case provides an excuse for the United States to interfere in the South China Sea.

column1: Looking back
column2: The Hague-based Permanent Court of Arbitration (PCA) charged the arbitral tribunal for the South China Sea case 2.85 million euros (3.16 million dollars ) for the secretarial service.

column1: This was a sum all paid by Manila
column2: including the share supposed to have been borne by Beijing
column3: which had insisted on a stance of non-acceptance of and non-participation in the arbitration.

column1: This cost is supposed to cover human labor and rents for office and office equipment
column2: as well as possible payments to the five members of the arbitral tribunal
column3: said Wang Hanling
column4: a Chinese maritime law expert at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences.

column1: A gross sum of partial expenses can be traced on the basis of open data
column2: Wang said. For instance
column3: charges of secretarial service include openly-priced human labor
column4: a single payment of 2
column5: 000 euros (2
column7: and daily rent of office equipment at 1
column11: and the hearings room is charged at 1

column1: Such estimations can lead to a conclusion that the arbitrators pocketed largely the money Manila paid
column2: Wang wrote in an article published on July 28 in China's Global Times newspaper.

column1: The PCA charges are the only part made public of the expenses of the arbitration case
column2: Wang said.

column1: Setting a rare precedent in the history of international justice and arbitration by sweepingly siding with Manila's claims
column2: the arbitral award has been widely questioned and challenged in the world. What's worse
column3: it indicates something fishy about the arbitrators
column4: Wang said.

column1: Wang believes that certain countries such as the United States and Japan
column2: and some organizations
column3: probably have invested a great deal of money and resources in the South China Sea arbitration case
column4: citing the first payment by some U.S. institutions.

column1: However
column2: what Manila finally gained from the arbitration case is nothing but a scrap of paper
column3: instead of benefits
column4: he said.

column1: In this regard
column2: it is necessary for Manila to open the records of expenses for the arbitration
column3: so as to respond to the questions raise by the Philippine people and address the concerns of the international community
column4: Wang concluded.

column1: c_135535820.htm|2016-07-24| Commentary: East Asia needs partners, not meddlers|
by Xinhua Writer Liu Chang
BEIJING
column2: July 24 (Xinhua) -- The Asia-Pacific boasts the world's most dynamic economies
column3: highly lucrative markets and captivating cultural diversity. It could well become the future of the world. Yet some meddlers are jeopardizing that prospect.

column1: Starting from Sunday
column2: foreign ministers of the East Asia Summit countries will be under the same roof in the Laotian capital of Vientiane for a series of meetings. The coming days are a chance for the top diplomats to start engaging in damage control after the recent null and void award on the South China Sea arbitration
column3: a blow to peace and stability in the region.

column1: Worryingly
column2: the arbitration
column3: a unilateral move by the Philippines
column4: has set a fraught and dangerous precedent of mishandling maritime disputes. Worse still
column5: a handful of countries within and outside the region have urged China to follow the ruling by a highly questionable arbitral tribunal in The Hague
column6: which has clearly acted beyond its jurisdiction. The ruling by no means helps solving the problem by peaceful ways and only serves to increase the likelihood of confrontation and turbulence.

column1: In a latest positive sign
column2: former Philippine President Fidel Ramos has accepted the offer of President Rodrigo Duterte to be special envoy to China
column3: opening the possibility of dialogue between Beijing and Manila. It is a testimony that the South China Sea disputes can be solved by directly involved parties
column4: without the interference from outsiders.

column1: Still
column2: the risks of rising tensions
column3: fanned by a few countries may not be underestimated.

column1: Despite Washington's denial
column2: it clearly has a hand in this. During the past eight years
column3: the Obama administration has mostly seen China as a potential challenger to its ""leadership"" in the region and has been seeking to curb its rise with its iconic ""Pivot to Asia"" policy.

column1: By excluding China
column2: the world's second-largest economy
column3: from the Trans-Pacific Pact
column4: Washington tries to be the only one who wears the pants in the region.

column1: Meanwhile
column2: the United States has left no stone unturned to sow discord between China and its neighbors. In the South China Sea
column3: the United States paints China as a threat to freedom of navigation and accuses it of weaponizing the area. On the Korean Peninsula

column1: c_135507910.htm|2016-07-12| Spotlight: Busting myths of South China Sea arbitration|
By Yang Dingdu
column2: Ling Shuo

column1: THE HAGUE
column2: July 12 (Xinhua) -- The tribunal handling the South China Sea arbitration case unilaterally initiated by the former Philippine government issued its final award on Tuesday
column3: but as the panel has no jurisdiction
column4: its decision is naturally null and void.

column1: In a press release accompanying the 479-page award
column2: the five-member tribunal offered a summary of its decisions
column3: which sweepingly side with the claims filed by the administration of former Philippine President Benigno S. Aquino III.

column1: China has refused to participate in the proceedings
column2: reiterating that the tribunal has no jurisdiction over the case
column3: which is in essence related to territorial sovereignty and maritime delimitation.

column1: The Ministry of Foreign Affairs of the People's Republic of China solemnly declares that the award is null and void and has no binding force. China neither accepts nor recognizes it
column2: the ministry said in a statement shortly after the publication of the award.

column1: It should be the ultimate goal of any international institution to help resolve conflicts
column2: maintain peace and limit armaments. These were also the founding principles of the Permanent Court of Arbitration (PCA) when it was established over a hundred years ago.

column1: However
column2: the arbitral tribunal the PCA organized over the South China Sea issue seems to have intensified the disputes between Beijing and Manila
column3: putting regional peace at risk while spurring military buildup. Questions have been raised over the legitimacy of the arbitration.

column1: STALLED TALKS
Before the arbitration was filed
column2: China and the Philippines
column3: along with other countries involved
column4: had engaged in constructive talks over disputes in the South China Sea for years.

column1: Those talks yielded a declaration that regulates the conduct of involved parties in the waterway so as to ensure regional peace. The parties also fostered a ""dual track"" approach of maintaining peace while holding talks on disputes.
However
column2: it became difficult to hold talks ever since the administration of former Philippine President Benigno S. Aquino III initiated the arbitration in 2013. Dialogues were disrupted after the tribunal claimed jurisdiction two years later.

column1: Since talks stalled
column2: tensions have mounted. U.S. warships and planes have frequented the South China Sea under the pretext of safeguarding ""freedom of navigation and overflight.""

column1: Meanwhile
column2: Washington and Manila held a slew of joint military drills near the waters of the South China Sea. The scale of their war games kept increasing while the weapons used by their servicemen became increasingly sophisticated.

column1: In April
column2: thousands of U.S.
column3: Philippine and Australian troops attended an 11-day exercise in the South China Sea region
column4: which deployed the High Mobility Artillery Rocket System
column5: capable of firing waves of rockets and missiles from a long range with great accuracy.

column1: The high-profile U.S. military presence only cast a pall on the otherwise peaceful South China Sea
column2: through which more than 100
column3: 000 ships pass annually without incidents.

column1: LAWFARE""
The U.S. intervention won't end with military muscle-flexing. Observers said that the arbitration is part of the ""lawfare"" that the United States has waged against China
column2: by manipulating lawsuits and legal systems to tarnish China's claims and rights.

column1: Although the arbitration was initiated by the Aquino III administration in 2013
column2: U.S. support and abetment were crucial to its being carried forward. The 3
column3: 000-page documents that the Philippines handed over to the tribunal were compiled with the help of U.S. legal experts who also participated in the process of deliberations.

column1: The U.S. support
column2: analysts said
column3: is also a key factor that encouraged the tribunal to accept and then claim jurisdiction over the flawed case.

column2: then U.S. Secretary of State Hillary Clinton declared that Washington has national interests in the South China Sea
column3: amid the U.S.strategic shift to the Asia-Pacific region.

column1: The United States and the Philippines issued a joint statement to back the arbitration in 2014. Later that year
column2: U.S. President Barack Obama
column3: during a visit to Manila
column4: voiced his support for the arbitration.

column1: QUESTIONABLE JURISDICTION
Outwardly
column2: Manila's request was to determine the nature of features ""under Chinese control"" in the South China Sea. But its real agenda was to confuse the maritime rights assigned to different features
column3: e.g. islands
column4: low-tide elevations or submerged banks
column5: with China's sovereignty over the Nansha Islands and its waters.

column1: By dwelling on the nature of the features
column2: the Philippines has attempted to limit China's maritime rights and interests to individual features
column3: denying China's historic rights over the Nansha Islands as a whole.

column1: Hence
column2: the Philippines' requests are essentially about territorial sovereignty and maritime delimitation. Territorial issues are subject to general international law rather than the United Nations Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS)
column3: under which the tribunal operates.

column1: In addition
column2: China excluded disputes concerning maritime delimitation
column3: historic bays or titles from UNCLOS dispute settlement procedures in 2006
column4: according to the UNCLOS stipulation.

column1: HISTORICAL FACTS
Before the colonization of Southeast Asia by Western powers
column2: the South China Sea had been a peaceful and prosperous hub for trade and cultural exchanges for over a thousand years.

column1: In AD 671
column2: the Chinese monk Yi Jing set sail across the South China Sea to study Buddhism in India and came back 25 years later. During his journey
column3: Yi visited 30 ancient countries in the South China Sea region
column4: during which he shared Chinese culture and technology with his hosts.

column1: Yi was among more than 60 Chinese monks who traveled through the South China Sea to India during that period. Their writings and travel logs are evidence that proves China's active role in promoting peace and prosperity in the waters.
In various Chinese dynasties
column2: offices on sea affairs were set up
column3: along with the launch of coast patrols to ensure safe passage in the waterway. For about a hundred years
column4: China had worked with the state of Malacca to combat piracy in the South China Sea
column5: until Malacca was colonized by Portugal in 1611.

column1: MEDIA MISINFORMATION
China's rights over the South China Sea are backed by numerous historical records. However
column2: some Western media have either turned a blind eye to the facts or twisted them to make up their own version of the ""truth.""

column1: In Tanmen
column2: a fishing village in southern China
column3: a retired fisherman told BBC that he once had an ancient book with navigation directions to the South China Sea. But he threw it away as it was no longer readable after being used for hundreds of years.

column1: Upon hearing this
column2: the BBC reporter started to question the existence of the book
column3: suggesting the old fisherman
column4: who had trusted him with his family story
column5: was lying. He went on to accuse Chinese media
column6: which had first reported on the book
column7: of having made up the story to bolster China's claims.

column1: Had the reporter bothered to visit the Hainan Provincial Museum
column2: he would have seen those ancient navigation guides on public display.

column1: In fact
column2: generations of fishermen living in a number of harbors in Hainan have relied on such ancient guides to navigate in the South China Sea. At least 12 versions of them can be found in museums or fishing villages.

column1: NEGOTIATION THE ONLY WAY
Any ultimate resolution of territorial issues must be based on the will of the states involved. History
column2: national interests and people's feelings of each side need to be acknowledged and taken into consideration before any reconciliation and agreement can be achieved.

column1: A rushed decision by a third party often leads to more disputes and conflicts. In Southeast Asia alone
column2: problematic demarcations by colonists left Malaysia
column3: Thailand
column4: Indonesia and Cambodia with long-standing land disputes among them and even separatist violence.

column1: The South China Sea issue involves waters of 3.5 million square kilometers and several parties in the region. Its magnitude and complexity far exceed the capacity of any tribunal.
In addition
column2: China has made it clear that the arbitration is illegal
column3: null and void
column4: and that the country does not accept it or participate in it.

column1: Without China's acknowledgement and support
column2: the ""award"" of the arbitration is practically infeasible
column3: or ""just a piece of paper
column4: as described by former Chinese State Councilor Dai Bingguo.

column1: China will never give up our lawful rights. Chinese people do not believe in fallacy nor are we afraid of evil forces
column2: Chinese President Xi Jinping said on July 1
column3: commemorating the 95th founding anniversary of the Communist Party of China.

column1: Chinese people do not make trouble
column2: but we are not cowards when involved in trouble
column3: Xi said.

column1: The newly-elected Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte has on multiple occasions shown willingness to resume talks with the Chinese side
column2: a good starting point for reconciliation and mutual understanding between the two countries.

column1: Hopefully
column2: this ""piece of paper"" can serve as a lesson to remind all parties involved that there is no shortcut to resolving the South China Sea issue
column3: and that the final solution to it can only be found at the negotiation table.

column2: arbitration isn't a panacea to solving disputes. Instead
column3: it more likely creates more disputes and stokes regional tensions
column4: doing harm to the fundamental interests of peoples in the region.

column1: BUENOS AIRES
column2: June 13 (Xinhua) -- The Philippines' ongoing maritime dispute with China over the South China Sea must be resolved through reasoned bilateral dialogue

column2: Gustavo Girado
column3: head of the Buenos Aires-based Asia & Argentina Consultancy

column2: Manila decided to take its case to the Permanent Court of Arbitration (PCA) in The Hague
column3: a move that ""didn't seem to be the most appropriate
column4: since the decade-old agreements between the two countries have established a proper means to resolve their disputes
column5: said Girado.

column1: The unilateral move ran counter to the commitments the Philippines made as a signatory of the 2002 Declaration on the Conduct of Parties in the South China Sea (DOC)
column2: said the academic.

column1: The road the Philippines chose draws attention somewhat due to a number of factors which failed to justify that action
column2: historic and political factors
column3: said Girado.

column1: It's very clear that Chinese inhabitants were the first to name the region
column2: he added.

column1: On Wednesday
column2: China again urged the Philippines to suspend its legal proceedings at the PCA and return to the negotiating table.

column1: Chinese Foreign Ministry spokesperson Hong Lei made the remarks at a press conference
column2: saying the door to bilateral talks will always be open.

column1: China will continue to be committed to a negotiated solution to the South China Sea dispute with the Philippines
column2: based on historic facts and in accord with international law
column3: he said.

column1: Girado believes the dispute ""doesn't merit intervention by third parties
column2: such as an arbitration court
column3: which ""belongs to the last century.""

column2: the Chinese Foreign Ministry issued a Position Paper on the arbitration
column3: saying that the essence of the subject matter of the case is territorial sovereignty over several maritime features in the South China Sea
column4: which is beyond the scope of the UN Convention on the Law of the Sea (UNCLOS) under which Manila initiated the arbitration.

column1: China has repeatedly noted that since the 1970s
column2: the Philippines has illegally seized by force maritime features of China's Nansha Islands in disregard of the UN Charter and the basic norms governing international relations
column3: and this is ""the root and direct cause"" of the two countries' disputes over the South China Sea.

column1: It's appropriate for China not to take into consideration the resolution of arbitration
column2: given the previous accord that allows for reaching a mutual agreement through peaceful
column3: responsible negotiation
column4: Girado said.

column1: Law of the Sea legislation precisely says that those who have a previous accord for bilateral resolution of disputes must take that route
column2: he said.

column1: With that in mind
column2: said the academic
column3: it seems ""clear and wise on the part of Chinese diplomacy not to take into account any eventual decision (issued by the PCA)
column4: because it doesn't take into account China's opinion.""

column1: As to the likelihood of outside powers intervening in the dispute
column2: Girado thought it's ""evident."" He explained that since U.S. President Barack Obama's first term
column3: a policy has been established for the region
column4: with the U.S. Navy's presence in a certain area in order to exert a degree of influence on matters of interest to the United States.

column1: It's a tremendously rich zone
column2: through which half of the planet's maritime mercantile trade passes. I have no doubt there are concrete interests at play in the Filipino decision
column3: which really calls one's attention

column1: Since the islands ""were usurped by the world's leading capitalist economy back in the year 1833
column2: different interests have been at play to prevent Argentina
column3: a developing country
column4: from staking a claim to what belongs to it.""

column2: China said it hoped the new government in the Philippines would return to the negotiating table.

column2: Oct. 18 (Xinhua) -- If Vice President Jejomar Binay will win in the 2016 presidential elections
column3: he would be the best example of how a political dynasty can control national and local politics in the Philippines.

column4: and a son

column1: The issue of political dynasties is not new in the Philippines and is not limited to the political opposition led by Binay.
In fact
column2: incumbent President Benigno Aquino III is a third generation member of a well-known political dynasty. He is the son of the late President Corazon Aquino and the martyred Senator Benigno Aquino
column3: Jr. His grandfather
column4: the late Benigno Aquino
column5: Sr.
column6: was one-time speaker of the House of Representatives.

column1: Interior Secretary Manuel Roxas
column2: the presumptive opponent of Binay in the 2016 presidential race
column3: is also a third generation politician from a political clan. His late father
column4: Gerry Roxas
column5: was a senator and his grandfather was the first president of the Philippine Republic.

column1: The list of the current crop of politicians who are members of political dynasties can go on and on.
In the Philippine Senate alone
column2: three are sons of former presidents. The siblings Jinggoy Estrada and J.V. Ejercito are both sons of former President Joseph Estrada
column3: who was ousted by a military-backed civilian uprising after only two years in office.

column1: Senator Ferdinand ""Bongbong"" Marcos is the son of the late dictator Ferdinand Marcos. He is rumored to have ambitions to run in the 2016 presidential derby. His mother
column2: the former First Lady Imelda Romualdez Marcos
column3: now 84
column4: is a congresswoman representing the province of Ilocos Norte in northern Luzon while a sister is the governor of the province.

column1: Is there no end to the dominance of family dynasties in Philippine politics?
A number of bills have been filed in both houses of Congress precisely to put an end to political dynasties as provided for in the Philippine Constitution.
Section 26
column2: Article II of the 1987 Constitution states ""The state shall guarantee equal access to opportunities for public service
column3: and prohibit political dynasties as may be defined by law. ""

column1: But since l987
column2: the Philippine Congress has failed to enact an enabling law that would implement the constitutional prohibition of political dynasties.

column1: In Senate Bill 2649
column2: also known as the Anti-Political Dynasty Act
column3: Senator Miriam Defensor-Santiago defines a dynasty as a situation when an incumbent official's spouse or his or her second- degree relatives hold or seek office together
column4: or when a spouse or relative succeeds him or her.

column1: Santiago said that her bill would level the playing field of the political arena and would open it to persons who are equally qualified to aspire for government elective posts but who cannot hope to win against well-entrenched politically-dominant families.
In many instances
column2: voters
column3: for convenience and out of cultural mindset
column4: look up to these ruling families as dispensers of favors and thus elect them or their relatives to public office
column5: Santiago said.

column1: Supreme Court Justice Antonio Carpio has defined political dynasties as a ""phenomenon that concentrates political power and public resources within the control of a few families whose members alternately hold elective offices
column2: deftly skirting term limits.""

column1: One good example of how politically-entrenched families can circumvent the law is Mayor Rodrigo Duterte of Davao City in the southern Philippines. The feisty mayor is known for his extra- legal methods in going after the city's hoodlums.
Under the law
column2: a local official can only hold office for three consecutive terms of three years each. When Duterte's nine-year term as city mayor ended
column3: he pushed his daughter to run for mayor and he as vice mayor and both of them won. After his daughter's term as mayor lapsed
column4: Duterte again run for mayor and has since regained his post.

column1: Duterte's case is being replicated in other cities and provinces in the country where members of political dynasties take turn in holding elective posts to the exclusion of other individuals who cannot win an election because of lack of resources.

A recent study by the Philippine Center for Investigative Journalism traced the emergence of political dynasties in the Philippines to the introduction by the Americans of electoral politics in the early 20th century
column2: when voting was initially limited to the rich and the landed
column3: who then monopolized public office.

column1: The study said that the motive behind political dynasties is primarily to protect the families' interests in the legislature and executive branches of the government to the detriment of the majority.
Political dynasties are a terrible indictment of the kind of politics we have

column3: Jr. ""I do not believe that any one family has the monopoly of talent to run the government.""

column1: But Pimentel was being dishonest in his observation. His son and namesake

column1: c_135736482.htm|2016-10-07| Philippines ""can live"" without U.S. military aid: defense chief"|"
MANILA
column2: Oct. 7 (Xinhua) -- Philippine Defense Secretary Delfin Lorenzana said on Friday that the Philippines can get by without U.S. military aid.

column2: saying the two countries are ""just going through bumps on the road.""

column1: We should not
column2: according to the president
column3: be dependent on one country alone. We should spread our side to others because there are still so many countries there

column1: In fact
column2: he said the ambassadors of India and Russia have offered some sophisticated equipment that Washington has not offered. ""I see this as a healthy development between our relationship
column3: he said.

column1: Lorenzana said he favored the review of the Enhanced Defense Cooperation Agreement (EDCA) which Manila and Washington signed in 2014.

U.S. and Philippine defense and military officials are to meet later this month to thresh out the issues concerning military-to-military relations between the two nations. Lorenzana said the EDCA might be discussed at the meeting.
In recent weeks

column1: Lorenzana reiterated that the Philippines will not abrogate its treaty with the U.S.
column2: saying that Duterte only wants to chart an foreign policy that is not dependent to one country.

column1: No worries

column1: MANILA

column1: In an interview with reporters
column2: Duterte said his declaration of state of lawlessness ""would require nationwide
column3: well-coordinated efforts of the military and the police.""

column1: He clarified that it is not a declaration of martial law.
I have this duty to protect the country. I have this duty to keep intact the integrity of the nation

column1: Death toll from the explosion reached 14

column1: In a separate statement

column1: It is a different case from the existence of invasion or rebellion. Only if there is invasion or rebellion

column1: According to Interior and Local Government Secretary Mike Sueno

column1: Duterte came from Davao City and his daughter and son are the mayor and vice-mayor
column2: respectively
column3: of the city.

column1: They will also aid in gathering intelligence information and in conducting investigations to get to the bottom of this unfortunate incident

c_135636693.htm|2016-08-26| Philippine gov't, leftist rebels agree to work for joint truce|

column2: showing pride yet with a smile on his face. ""I portrayed him as someone who is approachable and humble
column3: Bongabong said. ""I guess my hard work paid off.""

column1: Bongabong
column2: knows as Macky to his friends
column3: is virtually unknown in the art world. Except for some friends and clients who go to his fine arts kiosk inside a shopping mall in Davao
column4: Duterte's home city
column5: Bongabong said nobody really knows his work.

column1: Who would have thought that someone would notice my talent as a painter?"" Bongabong said.
It all started sometime in August when a staff from the Office of the President dropped a note to Bongabong's rented kiosk in a shopping mall in Davao.

I was nervous when I saw the stationery that said Office of the President Manila. I called the mobile number written on it and heard the good news. I was being asked to do a portrait of our beloved president. I was nervous and excited at the same time
column2: he recalled.

column1: Bongabong said the task was scary for someone who has no formal training in painting.
I could feel the tremendous pressure on my shoulders. But I accepted the challenge. I didn't want my insecurities to get in the way
column2: he said.

column1: The Office of the President emailed Duterte's photo to Bongabong ""for guidance.""
For the next 30 days
column2: Bongabong said he was sketching
column3: painting and mixing colors on his palette to create a ""natural"" Duterte. ""I made sure that the colors popped
column4: he said
column5: adding that he wanted the painting to be ""alive.""

column1: He considers the portrait painting to be his greatest work so far
column2: earning glowing compliments from the palace. ""I was told my portrait was both natural and vibrant
column3: he said.

column1: He added
column2: ""I consider it a labor of love. Every single day for a month I was happy to wake up and paint somebody I know
column3: I respect and look up to. Plus I think the emotions that I put into it
column4: my life struggles and experiences went into every inch of detail with each brush stroke.

column1: On Oct. 16
column2: Bongabong personally presented the portrait painting to Duterte at the Davao international airport before the leader left for his state visits to Brunei and China.

column1: I cried. I was overwhelmed when I saw him. I was awed. He was very soft-spoken. He even joked that he would commission my team again for more paintings
column2: he said.

column1: It was a gift of love to President Duterte who we consider a tatay (father)
column2: he said.

column1: After their meeting that lasted several minutes
column2: Bongabong said Duterte invited him for dinner at the palace a few days later. It would be Bongabong's first time to set foot in the official residence and principal workplace of Philippine presidents.

column1: Also invited to the dinner were his two apprentices
column2: Keren Hanhah Golea and sister Krystle Ann Golea who also gave Duterte a charcoal painting of Duterte kissing his mother's hands. Golea's charcoal painting is also now hanging on the walls of Bahay Pangarap just across from the palace where Duterte lives when he is in Manila.

column1: Bongabong remembered his first fleeting encounter with then Davao City Mayor Duterte back in 2013. He said he and his friends went up to him at the mall and requested a photo to which the former mayor readily agreed. Little did he know that three years later he would be invited to have dinner with Duterte at the palace.

He said he is looking forward to the dinner with Duterte. ""I cannot ask for more. If that happens then I will just thank him again for appreciating my work and for giving me the opportunity to paint his portrait. It's a real honor and a privilege
column2: he said.

column1: Bongabong has indeed come a long way.
From the rural fishing village of Zamboanga
column2: the bachelor who runs a small art shop in a shopping mall will share dinner with the 71-year-old Duterte
column3: the Philippines' 16th president and the first president from Mindanao.

column1: Duterte is now immortalized in an official portrait that now hangs in the halls of power where artworks of known Filipino artists are also on display.

Bongabong's advice to aspiring painters is encouraging. ""Appreciate what you have and use it. Love your work and keep practicing to hone your skills. Always give it your best. Being poor is not hindrance
column2: the artist said.

column1: c_135791424.htm|2016-10-30| Commentary: Washington's anxieties in Asia-Pacific region|
by Xinhua writer Liu Chang
BEIJING
column2: Oct. 30 (Xinhua) -- In recent days
column3: Washington seems to be agonizing over the colorful rhetoric of Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte
column4: while its ""pivot to Asia"" policy faces even more uncertainties.

column1: The United States believes that it has some sort of natural rights to write what outgoing President Barack Obama called ""the rules of the road"" for the Asia-Pacific region. Moreover
column2: it wants all nations in the region to observe that same playbook.

column1: Yet without obedient partnerships underpinned by strong economic
column2: military and security cooperation
column3: America's such geopolitical arrangement could go nowhere.

column1: In recent months
column2: Washington has been troubled by a sense of worry.

column1: Since Duterte took office in late June
column2: the new leader in Manila has kept flashing out signals that have perplexed the Americans
column3: if not enraging them. Perhaps the U.S. leaders have now begun to miss the ""good old days"" when former Philippine President Benigno Aquino III was in power.

column1: Now that the Philippines has vowed to send all foreign troops home
column2: including the U.S. forces stationed in the Southeastern Asian country
column3: many are wondering how far Manila would go to push forward its independent foreign policy.

column1: While the Philippines seems to be pivoting away
column2: the bleak picture for the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) trade pact has also raised qualms of America's allies in the region about Washington's determination and ability to close the deal.

column1: The TPP is the economic magnet Washington tries to use to pull its regional partners together and to bolster its economic leadership in the Asia-Pacific. Its failure to be materialized
column2: which now seems very likely
column3: would sink the re-balance to Asia strategy deep down into the waves of the Pacific.

column1: Though Beijing has repeatedly promised to seek peaceful development
column2: the suspicious and stubborn Washington still tries to counterbalance it.

column1: In his recent article published in the Foreign Affairs magazine
column2: Ashton Carter
column3: U.S. defense chief
column4: criticized Beijing for being ""out of step with where the Asia-Pacific wants to go.""

column1: Considering America's intention to call the shots in the region
column2: the secretary could probably really mean ""where Washington wants to go.""

column1: The rapprochement between Beijing and Manila has gotten on the nerves of the U.S. government. That may explain why U.S. Navy destroyer Decatur intruded earlier this month the waters of China's Xisha Islands in the South China Sea.

At the very root of Washington's growing solicitude are its self-serving and arrogant ambition to maintain global hegemony and worries that its days of being the world's only superpower are in a ticking countdown.
If the United States wants to get rid of the anxieties
column2: it has to find its rightful place in the Asia-Pacific and the wider world
column3: and starts to act more constructively
column4: not coercively. Obsession with the vain dream of building a long-lasting global empire could ultimately turn its nightmares into reality.
